key: _gpt-5__How do the effects of growing cover crops between crop rows compare to growing them when a field is empty?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In perennial systems like orchards and vineyards, ground cover grown between crop rows generally produced similar grape yields in several trials.
[Statement 2]: Some trials in perennial systems reported lower grape yields when ground cover was grown between crop rows.
[Statement 3]: The effects of growing ground cover on perennial crops other than grapes were mixed.
[Statement 4]: Chestnut yields were higher when resident vegetation was grown between crop rows.
[Statement 5]: Avocado yields were lower when seeded grasses or legumes were grown between crop rows.
[Statement 6]: In inter-row settings, resident vegetation resulted in more birds and higher bird diversity compared to bare, tilled row-middles.
[Statement 7]: In inter-row settings, using cover crops without tillage resulted in more mushrooms and more mushroom species.
[Statement 8]: In arable systems, cover crops grown when fields were empty sometimes reduced weed numbers and weed species richness compared to no cover or winter fallow.
[Statement 9]: In arable systems, cover crops grown when fields were empty sometimes increased weeds compared to no cover or winter fallow.
[Statement 10]: In arable systems, cover crops grown when fields were empty sometimes had no effect on weeds compared to no cover or winter fallow.
[Statement 11]: The composition of the weed community also differed when off-season cover crops were used compared to having no cover or winter fallow.
[Statement 12]: Off-season cover crops produced mixed pest and disease outcomes compared to winter fallow or no cover.
[Statement 13]: Lettuces were less severely diseased in some comparisons when grown after off-season cover crops.
[Statement 14]: Broccoli and tomato seedling disease was often similar between fields with off-season cover crops and those with winter fallow or no cover.
[Statement 15]: Differences in tomato damage were inconsistent when comparing fields with off-season cover crops to those without.
[Statement 16]: The numbers of pests like mites, leafminers, and nematodes showed mixed or no consistent differences when using off-season cover crops.
[Statement 17]: The numbers of soil fungi also showed mixed or no consistent differences when using off-season cover crops.
[Statement 18]: Within arable crops using living mulches between crop rows, some comparisons found fewer aphids relative to having no cover.
[Statement 19]: Within arable crops using living mulches between crop rows, some comparisons also found fewer parasitized aphids relative to having no cover.

[Statement 1]: A replicated study from Denmark and a review based mainly in Japan found increased soil carbon under cover crops.
[Statement 2]: One study reported further increases in soil carbon when legumes were included in the cover crop mix.
[Statement 3]: One replicated USA trial found higher tomato yield from soils previously under a ryegrass cover crop.
[Statement 4]: Two controlled, randomized, replicated studies from India and Pakistan found higher soil organic carbon or increased grain yields when green manures were grown.

key: _gpt-5__What are the comparative effects of using green manures versus cover crops on soil organic carbon and crop yield?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In studies including Europe and sandy loam soils, reduced or no-tillage often increased soil organic carbon compared to conventional tillage.
[Statement 2]: Several studies and reviews reported higher carbon under no-tillage or reduced tillage.
[Statement 3]: One randomized, replicated trial in Spain found greater carbon under conventional tillage.
[Statement 4]: One Canadian trial found no effect of tillage on soil organic carbon.
[Statement 5]: Reduced tillage frequently maintained or increased soil organic matter.
[Statement 6]: Reduced tillage frequently improved soil structure.
[Statement 7]: Some studies found higher nutrient retention with reduced tillage.
[Statement 8]: One controlled, replicated trial found less carbon and nitrate in no-till soil, while conventionally tilled soil lost more.
[Statement 9]: The effects of different tillage practices on soil nitrogen were mixed.
[Statement 10]: Multiple replicated trials, including some in Europe, showed reduced soil loss and runoff under reduced tillage.
[Statement 11]: No-tillage increased soil loss when crop cover was absent.
[Statement 12]: Delaying ploughing until spring in Denmark and Norway reduced soil loss and nitrate leaching.
[Statement 13]: In replicated European and Indian trials, conventional ploughing and sub-soiling decreased soil crack size.
[Statement 14]: In replicated European and Indian trials, conventional ploughing and sub-soiling increased infiltration and water content.
[Statement 15]: Soil compaction responses to different tillage practices were mixed.
[Statement 16]: Some trials found reduced compaction under controlled traffic and reduced tillage.
[Statement 17]: Other trials found higher compaction under reduced tillage.
[Statement 18]: Yield responses to different tillage practices varied.
[Statement 19]: One Canadian study reported lower yields under minimum or no-tillage.
[Statement 20]: A U.S. study found higher yields with subsoiling.
[Statement 21]: A Portuguese study found no yield effect from the tillage treatment.
[Statement 22]: The soil types covered in the relevant studies include sandy loam among others.

_gpt-5__What evidence exists from studies in the USA regarding the impact of cover crops and crop residue management on crop yields?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across replicated, controlled studies conducted in the USA, cash crop yields with winter cover crops were sometimes lower than without cover crops in some comparisons.
[Statement 2]: In some comparisons from USA studies, cash crop yields with winter cover crops were higher than without cover crops.
[Statement 3]: Some USA studies showed no difference in cash crop yields with winter cover crops compared to without.
[Statement 4]: Some USA studies showed inconsistent differences in cash crop yields with winter cover crops.
[Statement 5]: One USA study on summer cover crops reported inconsistent yield differences.
[Statement 6]: USA studies reported higher cash crop yields when winter cover crops were legumes versus non-legumes.
[Statement 7]: USA studies reported higher cash crop yields when mixtures of legumes and grasses were used as winter cover crops versus when legumes were used alone.
[Statement 8]: In the action on retaining crop residues, yield effects were reported from Australia and China.
[Statement 9]: A USA study on retaining crop residues addressed soil erosion rather than yield.
[Statement 10]: USA yield impacts from retaining crop residues were not reported in the evidence set.

[Statement 1]: Within leys in crop rotations on sandy-loam soil, reducing the extent of grass pasture decreased undesirable nitrogen uptake by grasses.
[Statement 2]: Reducing the extent of grass pasture within leys in crop rotations on sandy-loam soil required lower fertilizer rates for subsequent crops.

parts.text:

[Statement 4]: Incorporating straw into soil resulted in reduced soil loss.

[Statement 6]: Adding mulch to crops can reduce erosion and runoff.
[Statement 7]: One trial reported that mulch improved soil structure and increased soil organic matter.

[Statement 12]: Amending soil with manures and agricultural composts can result in higher soil organic matter and carbon.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A replicated study from Denmark reported that reducing the extent of grass pasture within leys reduced undesirable nitrogen uptake by grasses.
[Statement 2]: Reducing the extent of grass pasture within leys required lower fertilizer application rates for subsequent crops on sandy-loam soil.
[Statement 3]: A controlled study in Finland found that clover leys had a higher abundance of spiders than a barley control.
[Statement 4]: A controlled study in Finland found that clover leys had fewer pest insects than a barley control.
[Statement 5]: A UK study found that one-year leys had significantly lower earthworm species richness than three-and-a-half-year leys.
[Statement 6]: A UK study found that one-year leys had significantly lower earthworm abundance than three-and-a-half-year leys.
[Statement 7]: A replicated UK study found that grass leys supported fewer plant species than nine other conservation measures.
[Statement 8]: Reverting arable land to permanent grassland showed no clear benefit to wildlife, including UK birds, wading birds in Denmark, grey partridges, brown hares, and plants in the Czech Republic.
[Statement 9]: One controlled before-and-after UK study found grey partridge numbers fell significantly following the reversion of arable land to permanent grassland.
[Statement 10]: Five studies assessing the reversion of arable land to permanent grassland found no clear benefit to birds.
[Statement 11]: A controlled before-and-after UK study reported a significant decline in grey partridge numbers after the reversion of arable land to permanent grassland.

parts.text:

[Statement 20]: Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals may inhibit crop growth, an effect that can be mitigated by timing.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Replicated trials from New Zealand and the UK testing nitrification inhibitors reported reduced nitrate losses and nitrous oxide emissions in three of five trials.
[Statement 2]: One trial testing nitrification inhibitors found no effect.
[Statement 3]: A separate trial found reduced nutrient and soil loss with aluminium sulphate application.
[Statement 4]: Three randomized, replicated studies measuring manure applications found reduced nutrient loss and higher nitrogen levels with farmyard or poultry manure.
[Statement 5]: One study found lower nutrient loss when farmyard manure was applied in winter rather than in autumn.
[Statement 6]: One controlled replicated study detected higher nitrate leaching following manure applications.
[Statement 7]: Two controlled, replicated trials from Spain and the United Kingdom found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss.
[Statement 8]: One trial found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure increased nutrient loss.
[Statement 9]: In a separate trial, molasses additions improved nutrient retention and increased barley yield.

_gpt-5__How do the effects of retaining crop residues on-site compare with incorporating plant material brought from elsewhere?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Retaining crop residues on-site has been associated with higher microbial biomass.
[Statement 2]: Retaining crop residues on-site has been linked to reduced water runoff, increased water storage, and reduced soil erosion.
[Statement 3]: Retaining crop residues on-site has shown mixed effects on soil physical properties.
[Statement 4]: Retaining crop residues on-site has been associated with higher soil organic carbon and nitrogen, though one trial showed this effect only when fertilizer was also applied.
[Statement 5]: Retaining crop residues on-site has been associated with higher yields, though in one trial this was only observed when combined with fertilizer application and no-tillage.
[Statement 6]: Incorporating plant material or crop remains, including straw, compost, and fresh plant material, has been associated with increased microbial biomass.
[Statement 7]: Incorporating plant material or crop remains has improved soil structure in some studies but showed no improvement in anaerobic compacted soils.
[Statement 8]: Incorporating plant material or crop remains has been linked to reduced soil loss, with mixed erosion effects depending on the soil type.
[Statement 9]: Incorporating plant material or crop remains has been associated with higher soil nitrogen and reduced nitrate leaching, although there were mixed results for processed wastes.
[Statement 10]: Incorporating plant material or crop remains has been associated with higher soil organic carbon, with one study finding larger soil aggregates and another finding higher carbon when straw was applied with NPK fertilizer.
[Statement 11]: Incorporating plant material or crop remains has led to higher yields for barley in Denmark and when residues were incorporated earlier in the season in the Philippines.
[Statement 12]: Incorporating allelopathic plant remains for weed control has shown reductions in weed growth, though the effects were sometimes variable or short-lived.
[Statement 13]: Incorporating allelopathic plant remains has shown mixed effects on pests.
[Statement 14]: Incorporating allelopathic plant remains has inhibited crop growth in some studies, an effect that could be mitigated by timing.
[Statement 15]: The effect of incorporating allelopathic plant remains on yields has ranged from positive to negative, depending on the comparison with weeded or unweeded controls.
[Statement 16]: Incorporating allelopathic plant remains for weed control resulted in profit that was higher than unweeded controls but not higher than weeded controls in one study.

[Statement 3]: Crop rotation can result in increased yields in some years or with certain rotation crops.
[Statement 4]: One study reported that crop rotation increased profit.
[Statement 5]: Including legumes in crop rotations increases the number of microbes and the diversity of soil animals.
[Statement 6]: Including forage crops in crop rotations reduces rainwater runoff and soil loss.
[Statement 7]: Crop rotation increases soil organic carbon, particularly when legumes are included.
[Statement 8]: Several trials found crop rotation increased soil organic matter, particularly when legumes were included.
[Statement 9]: One study showed that pest populations increased under crop rotation.
[Statement 10]: Pest and yield responses to crop rotation can vary depending on the specific rotation used and other treatments.
[Statement 11]: A study reported that crop rotation had no effect in some cases.
[Statement 12]: One trial found lower soil organic matter with longer crop rotations.

_gpt-5__On sandy loam soils, how do the effects of amending with municipal waste compost compare to amending with organic processing waste composts?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: On sandy loam soils, municipal waste compost reduced soil loss and water runoff in semi-arid settings.
[Statement 2]: High application rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure on sandy loam soils.
[Statement 3]: High application rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure reduced soil loss on sandy loam soils.
[Statement 4]: High application rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure also increased nutrient loss on sandy loam soils.
[Statement 5]: Adding molasses to organic processing waste composts improved nutrient retention on sandy loam soils.
[Statement 6]: Adding molasses to organic processing waste composts increased barley yield on sandy loam soils.
